Dr. Isaac Quintanilla Salinas consents in you sharing course material to your friends and family for learning purposes. Use the material to educate and uplift your community.


Dr. Isaac Quintanilla Salinas does not consent in you sharing course material to companies/corporations. Additionally, I do not consent in the use of course material for academic dishonesty. Exceptions are allowed for DASS-approved services.

title: Welcome!
text:
Environmental Impact
In order to run these large language models, companies need to use a large amounts of energy. This is because large servers are needed to both train and execute a model.

The LA Times reports the potential impact that running AI models in California.


Additionally, Time reports that a ChatGPT query uses ten times more energy than a Google search query, and global AI demands can consume of 1 trillion gallons of water by 2027.


There are also environmental justice questions about where these data centers are constructed.

title: Welcome!
text:
Worker Exploitation
The Washington Post and Time (Article 1 and Article 2) reported that AI companies utilize “digital sweatshops” to classify data points for model training.

There is a human cost from the Global South, both financially and mentally, to develop the AI models for users in the United States and Europe.


We must be conscious consumers and demand more from these companies to provide safe working conditions and livable wages.

NO

title: Statistical Inference
text:
What is Statistical Inference?

Drawing conclusions about a population based on a sample
Population = entire group
Sample = subset


Introduce the big idea: We want to make st

title: Statistical Inference
text:
Two Main Types of Inference

Estimation

Hypothesis Testing


We’ll be focusing on two fundamental techniques in inference. First, estimating population values (like the mean), and second, testing claims about the population.

title: Statistical Inference
text:
Estimation

Point Estimate: Single best guess (e.g., \(\hat \beta_1\))
Interval Estimate: Range likely to contain the true value


Point estimates are easy but not very informative. Intervals give us a sense of uncertainty, which is critical in inference.

title: Statistical Inference
text:
Hypothesis Testing

\(H_0\): No effect or difference

\(H_1\): Some effect or difference

We use sample data to support or reject \(H_0\)


Mention that \(H_0\) is the default assumption. We only reject it if the data give us strong enough evidence.

title: Statistical Inference
text:
Key Concepts and Tools

Sampling Distribution
Central Limit Theorem
Standard Error


These three concepts are foundational. Understanding them helps us assess how reliable our estimates are.

title: Statistical Inference
text:
p-values

Probability of observing data as extreme as this if \(H_0\) is true

Misinterpretation of p-values is common. Emphasize: low p-value means data is unusual under \(H_0\).

title: Statistical Inference
text:
Confidence Intervals

A range where we expect the true value to fall


Clarify interpretation: it’s not about the probability the parameter is inside the interval, but about the method producing accurate intervals in the long run.

title: Statistical Inference
text:
Hypothesis Tests
Hypothesis tests are used to test whether claims are valid or not. This is conducted by collecting data, setting the Null and Alternative Hypothesis.

title: Statistical Inference
text:
Null Hypothesis \(H_0\)
The null hypothesis is the claim that is initially believed to be true. For the most part, it is always equal to the hypothesized value.

title: Statistical Inference
text:
Alternative Hypothesis \(H_a\)
The alternative hypothesis contradicts the null hypothesis.

title: Statistical Inference
section: Example of Null and Alternative Hypothesis
text:
Example of Null and Alternative Hypothesis
We want to see if \(\beta\) is different from \(\beta^*\)



Null Hypothesis
Alternative Hypothesis




\(H_0: \beta=\beta^*\)
\(H_a: \beta\ne\beta^*\)


\(H_0: \beta\le\beta^*\)
\(H_a: \beta>\beta^*\)


\(H_0: \beta\ge\beta^*\)
\(H_0: \beta<\beta^*\)

title: Statistical Inference
text:
One-Side vs Two-Side Hypothesis Tests
Notice how there are 3 types of null and alternative hypothesis, The first type of hypothesis (\(H_a:\beta\ne\beta^*\)) is considered a 2-sided hypothesis because the rejection region is located in 2 regions. The remaining two hypotheses are considered 1-sided because the rejection region is located on one side of the distribution.



Null Hypothesis
Alternative Hypothesis
Side




\(H_0: \beta=\beta^*\)
\(H_a: \beta\ne\beta^*\)
2-Sided


\(H_0: \beta\le\beta^*\)
\(H_a: \beta>\beta^*\)
1-Sided


\(H_0: \beta\ge\beta^*\)
\(H_0: \beta<\beta^*\)
1-Sided

title: Statistical Inference
text:
Hypothesis Testing Steps

State \(H_0\) and \(H_1\)
Choose \(\alpha\)
Compute confidence interval/p-value
Make a decision


Walk through the steps slowly with an example in mind. Emphasize that \(\alpha\) is a threshold, not the actual probability of error.

title: Statistical Inference
text: Rejection Region

title: Statistical Inference
text:
Rejection Region


Code
alpha <- 0.05

# Critical values for two-tailed test
z_critical <- qnorm(1 - alpha / 2)

# Create data for the normal curve
x <- seq(-4, 4, length = 1000)
y <- dnorm(x)

df <- data.frame(x = x, y = y)

ggplot(df, aes(x = x, y = y)) +
  geom_line(color = "deepskyblue", size = 1) +
  geom_area(data = subset(df, x <= -z_critical), aes(y = y), fill = "firebrick", alpha = 0.5) +
  geom_area(data = subset(df, x >= z_critical), aes(y = y), fill = "firebrick", alpha = 0.5) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = c(-z_critical, z_critical), linetype = "dashed", color = "black") +
  theme_bw()

title: Statistical Inference
text:
Decision Making
Hypothesis Testing will force you to make a decision: Reject \(H_0\) OR Fail to Reject \(H_0\)

Reject \(H_0\): The effect seen is not due to random chance, there is a process making contributing to the effect.


Fail to Reject \(H_0\): The effect seen is due to random chance. Random sampling is the reason why an effect is displayed, not an underlying process.

title: Statistical Inference
text:
Decision Making: P-Value
The p-value approach is one of the most common methods to report significant results. It is easier to interpret the p-value because it provides the probability of observing our test statistics, or something more extreme, given that the null hypothesis is true.

If \(p < \alpha\), then you reject \(H_0\); otherwise, you will fail to reject \(H_0\).

title: Statistical Inference
text:
Decision Making: Confidence Interval Approach
The confidence interval approach can evaluate a hypothesis test where the alternative hypothesis is \(\beta\ne\beta^*\). The bootstrapping approach will result in a lower and upper bound denoted as: \((LB, UB)\).

If \(\beta^*\) is in \((LB, UB)\), then you fail to reject \(H_0\). If \(\beta^*\) is not in \((LB,UB)\), then you reject \(H_0\).

title: Statistical Inference
text:
Significance Level \(\alpha\)
The significance level \(\alpha\) is the probability you will reject the null hypothesis given that it was true.

In other words, \(\alpha\) is the error rate that a research controls.


Typically, we want this error rate to be small (\(\alpha = 0.05\)).

title: Statistical Inference
text:
What is Statistical Power

Statistical Power is the probability of correctly rejecting a false null hypothesis.
In other words, it’s the chance of detecting a real effect when it exists.

title: Statistical Inference
text:
Why Power Matters

Low power → high risk of Type II Error (false negatives)
High power → better chance of finding true effects
Common threshold: 80% power

title: Statistical Inference
text:
Errors in Inference



Type I
Reject \(H_0\) when true
False positive


Type II
Don’t reject \(H_0\) when false
False negative


Power
\(1 - P(\text{Type II})\)
Detecting a true effect




Power is often overlooked. It’s about how sensitive the test is to real effects. Larger samples increase power.

title: Statistical Inference
text:
Type I Error (False Positive)

Rejecting \(H_0\) when it is actually true
Probability = \(\alpha\) (significance level)


Type I errors happen when we detect an effect that doesn’t really exist. This is controlled by our chosen alpha level.

title: Statistical Inference
text:
Type II Error (False Negative)

Failing to reject \(H_0\) when it is actually false
Probability = \(\beta\)
Power = \(1 - \beta\)


Type II errors are often due to small sample sizes or high variability. Power analysis helps us plan to avoid these.

title: Statistical Inference
text:
Balancing Errors

Lowering \(\alpha\) reduces Type I errors, but increases risk of Type II errors.
To reduce both:

Increase sample size
Use more appropriate statistical tests



There’s a trade-off between these errors. We can’t eliminate both, but we can manage the risk based on the consequences of each type.

title: Statistical Inference
text:
What Affects Power?

Effect Size

Bigger effects are easier to detect

Sample Size (\(n\))

Larger samples reduce standard error

Significance Level (\(\alpha\))

Higher \(\alpha\) increases power (but riskier!)

Variability

Less noise in data = better power

title: Statistical Inference
text:
Boosting Power

Power = Probability of rejecting \(H_0\) when it’s false
Helps avoid Type II Errors
Driven by:

Sample size
Effect size
\(\alpha\)
Variability

Aim for 80% or higher

title: Statistical Inference
text:
Confidence Intervals

A confidence interval gives a range of plausible values for a population parameter.
It reflects uncertainty in point estimates from sample data.


Introduce confidence intervals as the natural next step after understanding sampling variability and standard error. Emphasize that point estimates are useful, but intervals give a more complete picture.

title: Statistical Inference
text:
Interpretation

“We are 95% confident that the true mean lies between A and B.”


This does not mean there’s a 95% chance the mean is in that interval.
It means: if we repeated the sampling process many times, 95% of the intervals would contain the true value.


This is one of the most common misconceptions. Clarify that the confidence is in the method, not any one interval.

title: Statistical Inference
text:
Factors Affecting CI Width

Sample size (\(n\)): larger \(n\) → narrower CI

Standard deviation (\(s\) or \(\sigma\)): more variability → wider CI

Confidence level: higher confidence → wider CI


Use this to summarize what controls how “precise” our confidence interval is. Give examples of each.

title: Statistical Inference
text:
Conducting HT of \(\beta_j\)


Code
xlm <- lm(Y ~ X, data = DATA)
summary(xlm)



xlm: name of the stored model
Y: Name of the outcome variable in DATA
X: Name of the Predictor Variable(s) in DATA
DATA: Name of the data set

title: Inference with Logistic Regression
text:
Model inference
We conduct model inference to determine if different models are better at explaining variation. A common example is to compare a linear model (\(g(\hat Y)=\hat\beta_0 + \hat\beta_1 X\)) to the mean of Y (\(\hat \mu_y\)). We determine the significance of the variation explained using an Analysis of Variance (ANOVA) table and F test.

title: Inference with Logistic Regression
text:
Model Inference
Given 2 models:
\[
g(\hat Y) = \hat\beta_0 + \hat\beta_1 X_1 + \hat\beta_2 X_2 + \cdots + \hat\beta_p X_p
\]
or
\[
g(\hat Y) = \bar y
\]

Is the model with predictors do a better job than using the average?

title: Inference with Logistic Regression
text:
Likelihood Ratio Test
The Likelihood Ratio Test is a test to determine whether the likelihood of observing the outcome is significantly bigger in a larger, more complicated model, than a simpler model.
It conducts a hypothesis tests to see if models are significantly different from each other.

title: Inference with Logistic Regression
text:
Conducting an LRT in R


Code
xlm <- glm(Y ~ X, data = DATA, family = binomial)
xlm0 <- glm(Y ~ 1, data = DATA, family = binomial)
anova(xlm0, xlm, test = "LRT")

title: Inference with Logistic Regression
text:
Example


Code
m0 <- update(m1, formula. = ~ 1)
anova(m0, m1, test = "LRT")


#> Analysis of Deviance Table
#> 
#> Model 1: death ~ 1
#> Model 2: death ~ recur + number + size
#>   Resid. Df Resid. Dev Df Deviance Pr(>Chi)    
#> 1       293     189.38                         
#> 2       290     166.43  3   22.953 4.13e-05 ***
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

text:
Model Inference
Model inference can be extended to compare models that have different number of predictors.

title: Inference with Logistic Regression
text:
Model Inference
Given:
\[

\]
\[
M2:\ g(\hat y) = \beta_0 + \beta_1 X_1  
\]
Let \(M1\) be the FULL (larger) model, and let \(M2\) be the RED (Reduced, smaller) model.

title: Inference with Logistic Regression
text:
Model Inference
He can test the following Hypothesis:

\(H_0\): The error variations between the FULL and RED model are not different.
\(H_1\): The error variations between the FULL and RED model are different.

Code
full <- glm(Y  ~  X1 + X2 + X3 + X4, DATA, family = binomial())
red <- glm(Y ~ X1 + X2, DATA, family = binomial())
anova(red, full, test = "LRT")

title: Inference with Linear Regression
text:
Testing \(\beta_j\)
\[
T = \frac{\hat\beta_j-\theta}{\mathrm{se}(\hat\beta_j)} \sim t_{n-p^\prime}
\]

\(n\): sample size
\(p^\prime\): number of \(\beta\)s

title: Inference with Linear Regression
text:
P-Value



Alternative Hypothesis
p-value




\(\beta>\theta\)
\(P(\hat\beta >T)=p\)


\(\beta<\theta\)
\(P(\hat\beta < T)=p\)


\(\beta\ne\theta\)
\(2\times P(\hat\beta >|T|)=p\)

title: Inference with Linear Regression
text:
Confidence Intervals
\[
\hat \beta_j \pm CV \times se(\hat\beta_j)
\]

\(CV\): Critical Value \(P(X<CV) = 1-\alpha/2\)
\(\alpha\): significance level
\(se\): Standard Error Function

Source
DF

F

title: Inference with Linear Regression
text:
Model Inference
Given:
\[
M1:\ \hat y = \beta_0 + \beta_1 X_1 + \beta_2 X_2
\]
\[
M2:\ \hat y = \beta_0 + \beta_1 X_1  
\]
Let \(M1\) be the FULL (larger) model, and let \(M2\) be the RED (Reduced, smaller) model.

title: Inference with Linear Regression
text:
Model Inference
He can test the following Hypothesis:

\(H_0\): The error variations between the FULL and RED model are not different.
\(H_1\): The error variations between the FULL and RED model are different.

title: Inference with Linear Regression
text:
Test Statistic
\[
\hat F = \frac{[SSE(RED) - SSE(FULL)]/[DFE(RED)-DFE(FULL)]}{MSE(FULL)}
\]
\[
\hat F \sim F[DFE(RED) - DFE(FULL), DFE(FULL)]
\]

title: Inference with Linear Regression
text:
Model Assumptions
When we are conducting inference linear regression, we will have to check the following conditions:

Linearity
Independence
Normality
Equal Variances
Multicollinearity (for MLR)

title: Inference with Linear Regression
text:
Linearity
Probably considered the most important assumption, but there must be a linear relationship between both the outcome variable (y) and a set of predictors (\(x_1\), \(x_2\), …).

title: Inference with Linear Regression
text:
Independence
The data points must not influence each other.

title: Inference with Linear Regression
text:
Normality
The model errors (also known as residuals) must follow a normal distribution.

title: Inference with Linear Regression
text:
Equal Variances
The variability of the data points must be the same for all predictor values.

title: Inference with Linear Regression
text:
Residuals
Residuals are the errors between the observed value and the estimated model. Common residuals include

Raw Residual
Standardized Residual
Jackknife (studentized) Residuals

title: Inference with Linear Regression
text:
Influential Measurements
Influential measures are statistics that determine how much a data point affects the model. Common influential measures are

Leverages
Cook’s Distance

title: Inference with Linear Regression
text:
Raw Residuals
\[
\hat r_i = y_i - \hat y_i
\]

title: Inference with Linear Regression
text:
Residual Analysis
A residual analysis is used to test the assumptions of linear regression.

title: Inference with Linear Regression
text:
QQ Plot
A qq (quantile-quantile) plot will plot the estimated quantiles of the residuals against the theoretical quantiles from a normal distribution function. If the points from the qq-plot lie on the \(y=x\) line, it is said that the residuals follow a normal distribution.

title: Inference with Linear Regression
text:
Residual vs Fitted Plot
This plot allows you to assess the linearity, constant variance, and identify potential outliers. Create a scatter plot between the fitted values (x-axis) and the raw/standardized residuals (y-axis).

title: Inference with Linear Regression
text:
Variance Inflation Factor
The variance inflation factor is a measurement on how much variables are collinear with each other. A value greater than 10 is a cause for concern and action should be taken.

title: Inference with Linear Regression
text:
Residual Analysis in R
Use the resid_df function to obtain the residuals of a model.


Code
rdf <- resid_df(LM_OBJECT)

title: Inference with Linear Regression
text:
Residual vs Fitted Plot


Code
ggplot(RDF, aes(fitted, resid)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_hline(yintercept = 0, col = "red")

title: Inference with Linear Regression
text:
QQ Plot


Code
ggplot(RDF, aes(sample = resid)) + 
  stat_qq() +
  stat_qq_line()

title: Inference with Linear Regression
text:
Example


Code
xlm <- lm(body_mass_g ~   island + species + flipper_length_mm,
          penguins)
dfxlm <- resid_df(xlm)

ggplot(dfxlm, aes(fitted, resid)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_hline(yintercept = 0, col = "red")

ggplot(dfxlm, aes(sample = resid)) + 
  stat_qq() +
  stat_qq_line()

When conducting a study, literature review and study design are as equally important as statistics.


If you don’t see variability in the data, something is wrong.


Focus on consistency in the methodology, not consistency in data.


Understand that you can be wrong, and that is okay.


Don’t let data influence the methodology during a study/experiment.

title: Data Generating Process
text:
Observations
An observation is the unit which contains information to be obtained.


Also known as experimental unit.

title: Data Generating Process
text:
Data
Data is information from a particular experimental unit. There can be more that one piece of information per experimental unit.

title: Data Generating Process
text:
Data Structure
The structure of the data can be represented in various forms:

A list of long numbers
Table

title: Data Generating Process
text: Tabular Form

title: Data Generating Process
text:
Measurements
Measurements are the processes where we represent an attribute of an experimental unit as either a number or category.

title: Data Generating Process
text:
Quantitative Measurements
Quantitative measurements are data measurements that take a numeric form.

title: Data Generating Process
text:
Qualitative Measurements
Qualitative measurements are data measurements that take a certain category.

title: Data Generating Process
text:
Value
A value is a description (number or category) of a specific attribute of an experimental unit.

title: Data Generating Process
text:
Variable
A variable is the descriptive attribute that we want to obtain from an experimental unit. In terms of a data set, the variable contains all the values of specific attribute in a sample.

title: Data Generating Process
text:
Research Question
A research question is designed to create new knowledge of certain phenomenons observed in the world.

This is designed by conducting a research projects that systematically answers the question.


The study design is the procedure in which data is collected to answer the question, while reducing any potential bias while conducting the study.

title: Data Generating Process
text:
Study Design
This is the procedure designed to answer a research question.

Entails procedures to collect data that answers a research question.


Dictates how the data will be analyzed.


Determines how the data is quanitified and what is the experimental unit.

title: Data Generating Process
text:
Sampling
Sampling is the process of selecting units from a population interest to collect data from.

Image Provided by Simply Psychology.

title: Data Generating Process
text:
Sampling
When Sampling you want to maintain these properties:

Representative sample
Large enough sample size

title: Data Generating Process
text:
Sampling Example
We want to answer the question, are people happy?

title: Data Generating Process
text:
Random Sampling
When sampling, we strive for random sampling

Each unit in the population of interest must have an equal probability of being selected for the study.
This ensures a representative population

title: Data Generating Process
text:
Independent Sampling
In addition to random sampling, we strive to make sure each unit is independent from each other.

The probability of UNIT A being sampled will not affect the probability of UNIT B to be sampled.

title: Data Generating Process
text:
Sampling Variation

Random samples may vary from the population of interest.
Due to randomness, samples many not look the or biased.
However, this is to be expected as because the sample will not be biased in one way or another.
Samples are then considered unbiased as long as experimental units were collected randomly.

title: Data Generating Process
text:
Data
The measurement collected from an experimental unit.

title: Data Generating Process
text:
Data Distribution
When thinking about data, we know an attribute is allowed to vary. With this variation, some numbers are more likely to be observed than others.

title: Data Generating Process
text:
Forest from the trees

Imamge Provided by Fine Art America.

title: Data Generating Process
text:
Sample

When inspecting data:

Do not focus on one individual data point.
See how data points is in relation to other data points.
See what is common
See what is rare

title: Data Generating Process
text:
Data Generation Process (DGP)
The data generation process is understanding how variation from the population is transferred to the data collected.

A population has a mechanism to produce data, understanding this mechanism is essential understanding the data.

title: Data Generating Process
text:
DGP
A populations DGP can be defined with the following characteristics:

The potential outcomes that can be observed when measuring
Each potential outcome will have a probability of being observed

The probability must be between 0 and 1

Sum of all the probabilities of each outcome will add up to 1

title: Data Generating Process
text:
Flipping a Coin
Flipping a coin results in either heads or tail. The probability for heads is 50%

The DGP of flipping a coin is the process of selecting an outcome, given the probability of both options are 50%.

title: Data Generating Process
text: Rolling a die

title: Data Generating Process
text:
Measuring Body Temperature





Image Provided by Thermofisher Scientific.

title: Data Generating Process
text:
Inference
How do we use DGP and sampling to understand the world?

We can use a sample to understand the DGP.


We can use the DGP to understand the sample.

title: Data Generating Process
text: Visualizing a DGP

title: Data Generating Process
text: Visualizing DGP

title: Data Generating Process
text: Example

title: Data Generating Process
text:
Statistical Model
\[
Y \sim F(\theta)
\]

\(Y\): A data value generated for DGP
\(F\): A generic mathematical model that describes the DGP
\(\theta\): Parameter controlling the shape and form of the DGP

title: Data Generating Process
text:
Statistical Model
\[
Y = \mu + \varepsilon
\]

\(\mu\): The average value we expect to see
\(\varepsilon \sim F(\cdot)\): Error Term

title: Data Generating Process
text:
Statistical Model
\[
Y = \mu + \varepsilon
\]


\(\mu\): Explained Part

This is what we expect to see if we took an educated guess
The educated guess can incorporate information that is related to \(Y\)


\(\varepsilon\): Unexplained Part

Randomness
Incorporates several types of variation

Measurement Error
Biological Error
Environmental Error

title: Numerical Data
text:
R Packages

csucistats
tidyverse

title: Numerical Data
text: Motivating Example

title: Numerical Data
text:
Summary Statistics
Summary statistics are used to describe the distribution of data.

title: Numerical Data
text:
Central Tendency
Central tendency is a statistical concept that refers to the central or typical value around which a set of data points tends to cluster. It is used to summarize and describe a data set by identifying a single representative value that provides insights into the data’s overall characteristics.

title: Numerical Data
text:
Variation
Variation in statistics refers to the extent to which data points in a dataset deviate or differ from a central tendency measure. Understanding variation is crucial for making informed decisions, drawing meaningful conclusions, and assessing the reliability of statistical analyses.

title: Numerical Data
text:
Minimum
The minimum (min) is the smallest value in the data.

title: Numerical Data
text:
Maximum
The maximum (max) is the largest value in the data.

title: Numerical Data
text:
Quartiles
Quartiles are three values (Q1, Q2, Q3) that divides the data into four subsets.

title: Numerical Data
text:
Q1
Q1 is the value signifying that a quarter of the data is lower than it.

title: Numerical Data
text:
Q2 - Median
Q2 is the value signifying that half of the data is below it.

The median also represents the central tendency of the data.

title: Numerical Data
text:
Q3
Q3 is the value signifying that 3 quarters of the data is below it.

title: Numerical Data
text:
Interquartile Range

\[
IQR = Q_3 - Q_1
\]

title: Numerical Data
text:
Range

\[
R = \mathrm{max} - \mathrm{min}
\]

title: Numerical Data
text:
How to identify the quartiles?

Sort the data
ID Max and Min
Find the amount of data the makes a quarter:

\(K=N/4\)

Create 4 groups using the sorted data

group by data size
If \(K\) has a decimal, the \(Kth\) value is quartile of each group.

title: Numerical Data
text:
Mean
Describe how you will find the mean of these numbers:


#> [1] 15 14 17  9 14

title: Numerical Data
text:
Mean
The mean is another measurement for central tendency.
\[
\bar X = \frac{1}{n}\sum^n_{i=1}X_i
\]

\(n\): total data points
\(X_i\): data points
\(i\): indexing data
\(\sum\): add all from first (bottom) to last (up)

title: Numerical Data
text:
Variance
The variance is a measurement on the average squared distance the data points are from the central tendency.
\[
s^2 = \frac{1}{n-1}\sum^n_{i=1}(X_i-\bar X)^2
\]

title: Numerical Data
text:
Standard Deviation
The standard deviation is a measurement on the average distance the data points are from the central tendency.
\[
s=\sqrt{s^2}
\]

title: Numerical Data
text:
Outliers
These are data points that seem to be highly distant from all other variables.

title: Numerical Data
text: Numerical Statistics in R

title: Numerical Data
text:
Mean

mean(DATA$VAR)

title: Numerical Data
text:
Median

median(DATA$VAR)

title: Numerical Data
text:
Standard Deviation

sd(DATA$VAR)

title: Numerical Data
text:
Variance

var(DATA$VAR)

title: Numerical Data
text:

quantile(DATA$VAR, probs = c(0.25, 0.5, 0.75))

title: Numerical Data
text:
Max and Min

max(DATA$VAR)
min(DATA$VAR)

title: Numerical Data
text:
Summary Statistics

num_stats(DATA$VAR)

title: Numerical Data
text:
Mr. Trash Wheel

num_stats(trashwheel$PlasticBottles)

#>   min   q25     mean median  q75  max       sd     var    iqr missing
#> 1   0 987.5 2219.331   1900 2900 9830 1650.449 2723984 1912.5       1

title: Numerical Data
text:
Histogram
A histogram is a graphical representation of the distribution or frequency of data points in a dataset. It provides a visual way to understand the shape, central tendency, and spread of a dataset by dividing the data into intervals or bins and showing how many data points fall into each bin as a bar.

title: Numerical Data
text:
Histogram R Code

ggplot(DATA, aes(VARIABLE)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = X)

title: Numerical Data
text:
Histogram


Code
y <- rnorm(1000)
ggplot(tibble(y), aes(y)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 15)

title: Numerical Data
text:
Histogram


Code
y <- rgamma(1000, 2)
ggplot(tibble(y), aes(y)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 15)

title: Numerical Data
text:
Histograms


Code
y <- rbeta(1000, 5, 1)
ggplot(tibble(y), aes(y)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 15)

title: Numerical Data
text:
Histograms


Code
y <- rbinom(1000, 1, 0.4)
z <- (y == 0) * rnorm(1000, 23) + (y == 1) * rnorm(1000, 27)
ggplot(tibble(z), aes(z)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 15)

title: Numerical Data
text:
Mr. Trash Wheel

ggplot(trashwheel, aes(PlasticBottles)) +
  geom_histogram()

title: Numerical Data
text:
Box Plot
A box plot, also known as a box-and-whisker plot, is a graphical representation of the distribution and key statistical characteristics of a dataset. It provides a visual summary of the data’s central tendency, spread, and potential outliers.

title: Numerical Data
text: Box Plot

title: Numerical Data
text:
Box Plot R Code

ggplot(DATA, aes(VARIABLE)) +
  geom_boxplot()

title: Numerical Data
text:
Box Plot

ggplot(trashwheel, aes(PlasticBottles)) +
  geom_boxplot()

title: Numerical Data
text:
Box Plot

ggplot(trashwheel, aes(y = PlasticBottles)) +
  geom_boxplot()

title: Numerical Data
text:
Dot Plots
Dot Plots are similar to histograms, but they incorporate dots to count how many data points fall within bins.

title: Numerical Data
text:
Dot Plots in R

ggplot(DATA, aes(VARIABLE)) +
  geom_dotplot(binwidth = X)

title: Numerical Data
text:
Dot Plots


Code
ggplot(trashwheel, aes(PlasticBottles)) +
  geom_dotplot(binwidth = 100)

title: Numerical Data
text:
Transformed Data
When working with skewed data, it may be beneficial to transform the data to identify trends.


\(Y = \ln(X)\)
\(Y = \frac{1}{X}\)
\(Y = \sqrt X\)

title: Numerical Data
text:
Example


Code
library(patchwork)
y <- rlnorm(1000, mean = 0, sd = 2)
ly <- log(y)

p1 <- ggplot(tibble(y), aes(y)) +
  geom_histogram() +
  ggtitle("Skewed Data")
p2 <- ggplot(tibble(y = ly), aes(y)) +
  geom_histogram() +
  ggtitle("Log-Transformed Data")

p1 + p2

title: Numerical Data
text:
Scatter Plots
Scatter plots demonstrate how two variables behave with each other. They can tell you any postive or negative trends, if they exist, with the combination of the plots.

title: Numerical Data
text: Positive Relationship

title: Numerical Data
text: Negative Relationship

title: Numerical Data
text: No Relationship

text: Weak Positive or Negative Relationship

ggplot(DATA, aes(x = VAR1, y = VAR2)) +
  geom_point()

ggplot(trashwheel, aes(PlasticBottles, PlasticBags)) +
  geom_point()

Transformed Data

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Explaining Variation

This is the process where we try to reduce the variation with the use of other variables.


Can be thought of as getting it less wrong when taking an educated guess.

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Explaining Variation


Code
ggplot(penguins, aes(body_mass_g)) +
  geom_density()

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Variation with One Variable


Code
ggplot(penguins, aes(body_mass_g, fill = species)) +
  geom_density(alpha = .5)

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Generated Model
\[
Y \sim DGP_1
\]

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
A Simple Model


Code
ggplot(penguins, aes(body_mass_g)) +
  geom_density()

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
A Simple Model
\[
Y = \_\_\_ + error
\]

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Notation
\[
Y = \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ + \varepsilon
\]

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
The Simple Generated Model
\[
Y \sim \beta_0 + \varepsilon
\]
\[
\varepsilon \sim DGP_2
\]

\(DGP_2\) is not the same as the \(DGP_1\), it is transformed due \(\beta_0\). Consider this the NULL \(DGP\).

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Observing Data
\[
Y = \beta_0 + \varepsilon
\]

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Estimated Line
\[
\hat Y=\hat\beta_0
\]

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Notation


Observed
\[
Y = \beta_0 + \varepsilon
\]

Estimated
\[
\hat Y = \hat \beta_0
\]

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Indexing Data
The data in a data set can be indexed by a number.

penguins[1,-c(1:2)]

#> # A tibble: 1 × 6
#>   bill_length_mm bill_depth_mm flipper_length_mm body_mass_g sex    year
#>            <dbl>         <dbl>             <int>       <int> <fct> <int>
#> 1           39.1          18.7               181        3750 male   2007



Making the variable “body_mass_g” be represented by \(Y\) and “flipper_length_mm” as \(X\):
\[
Y_1 = 3750 \ \ X_1=181
\]

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Indexing Data
\[
Y_i, X_i
\]

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Data
With the data that we collect from a sample, we hypothesize how the data was generated.

Using a simple model:
\[
Y_i = \beta_0 + \varepsilon_i
\]

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Estimated Value
\[
\hat Y_i = \hat \beta_0
\]

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Estimation
To estimate \(\hat \beta_0\), we minimize the follow function:
\[
\sum^n_{i=1} (Y_i-\hat Y_i)^2
\]

This is known as the sum squared errors, SSE

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Residuals
The residuals are known as the observed errors from the data in the model:
\[
r_i = Y_i - \hat Y_i
\]

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Estimation in R

lm(Y ~ 1, data = DATA)


Y: Name Outcome Variable of Interest in data frame DATA
DATA: Name of the data frame

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Modeling Body Mass in Penguins

lm(body_mass_g ~ 1, data = penguins)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = body_mass_g ~ 1, data = penguins)
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#> (Intercept)  
#>        4207



\[
\hat Y = 4207
\]

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Visualize


Code
ggplot(penguins, aes(body_mass_g)) +
  geom_density() +
  geom_vline(xintercept = 4207)

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Linear Model
The goal of Statistics is to develop models the have a better explanation of the outcome \(Y\).

In particularly, reduce the sum of squared errors.


By utilizing a bit more of information, \(X\), we can increase the predicting capabilities of the model.


Thus, the linear model is born.

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Visualization

1-Dimensional2-Dimensional




Code
ggplot(penguins, aes(body_mass_g)) +
  geom_density()













Code
ggplot(penguins, aes(x = flipper_length_mm, y = body_mass_g, fill = after_stat(level))) +
  stat_density_2d(geom = "polygon")

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Linear Model
\[
Y = \beta_0 + \beta_1 X + \varepsilon
\]
\[
\varepsilon \sim DGP_3
\]

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Scatter Plot


Code
ggplot(penguins, aes(flipper_length_mm, body_mass_g)) + 
  geom_point()

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Imposing a Line


Code
ggplot(penguins, aes(flipper_length_mm, body_mass_g)) + 
  geom_point() +
  stat_smooth(method = "lm", se = F)

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Modelling the Data
\[
Y_i = \beta_0 + \beta_1 X_i + \varepsilon_i
\]

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Linear Model
\[
\hat Y_i = \hat \beta_0 + \hat \beta_1 X_i
\]

Goal is to obtain numerical values for \(\hat \beta_0\) and \(\hat \beta_1\) that will minimize the SSE.

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
SSE
\[
\sum^n_{i=1} (Y_i-\hat Y_i)^2
\]
\[
\hat Y_i = \hat \beta_0 + \hat \beta_1 X_i
\]

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Fitting a Model in R

lm(Y ~ X, data = DATA)


X: Name Predictor Variable of Interest in data frame DATA
Y: Name Outcome Variable of Interest in data frame DATA
DATA: Name of the data frame

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Example
Y: “body_mass_g”; X: “flipper_length_mm”

lm(body_mass_g ~ flipper_length_mm, data = penguins)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = body_mass_g ~ flipper_length_mm, data = penguins)
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>       (Intercept)  flipper_length_mm  
#>          -5872.09              50.15


\[
\hat Y_i = -5872.09 + 50.15 X_i
\]

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Interpretation of \(\hat\beta_0\)
The intercept \(\hat \beta_0\) can be interpreted as the base value when \(X\) is set to 0.

Some times the intercept can be interpretable to real world scenarios.


Other times it cannot.

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Interpreting Example
\[
\hat Y_i = -5872.09 + 50.15 X_i
\]
When flipper length is 0 mm, the body mass is -5872 grams.

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Interpretation of \(\hat \beta_1\)
The slope \(\hat \beta_1\) indicates how will y change when x increases by 1 unit.

It will demonstrate if there is, on average, a positive or negative relationship based on the sign provided.

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Interpreting Example
\[
\hat Y_i = -5872.09 + 50.15 X_i
\]
When flipper length increases by 1 mm, the body mass will increase by 50.15 grams.

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Body Mass with Species


Code
ggplot(penguins, aes(body_mass_g)) +
  geom_boxplot()

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Body Mass with Species


Code
ggplot(penguins, aes(body_mass_g, fill = species)) +
  geom_boxplot()

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Group Statistics
We can use statistics to explain a continuous variable by the categories.

Compute statistics for each group.



num_by_cat_stats(DATA, NUM, CAT)


NUM: Name of the numerical variable
CAT: Name of the categorical variable
DATA: Name of the data frame

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Compute Group Statistics

num_by_cat_stats(penguins, body_mass_g, species)

#>   Categories  min    q25     mean median  q75  max      sd      var   iqr
#> 1     Adelie 2850 3362.5 3706.164   3700 4000 4775 458.620 210332.4 637.5
#> 2  Chinstrap 2700 3487.5 3733.088   3700 3950 4800 384.335 147713.5 462.5
#> 3     Gentoo 3950 4700.0 5092.437   5050 5500 6300 501.476 251478.3 800.0
#>   missing
#> 1       0
#> 2       0
#> 3       0

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
LM with Categorical Variables
A line is normally used to model 2 continuous variables.

However, the predictor variable \(X\) can be restricted to a set a variables that can symbolize categories.


A category will be used as a reference for a model.

title: Simple Linear Regression
Simple Linear Regression
text:
Binary (Dummy) Variables
To fit a model with categorical variables, we must utilize dummy (binary) variables that indicate which category is being referenced. We use \(C-1\) dummy variables where \(C\) indicates the number of categories. When coded correctly, each category will be represented by a combination of dummy variables.

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:

If we have 4 categories, we will need 3 dummy variables:

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Linear Model
\[
\hat Y_i = \hat \beta_0 + \hat\beta_1 D_{1i} + \hat\beta_2 D_{2i}
\]

\(\hat \beta_1\) indicates how body mass changes from Adelie to Chinstrap.


\(\hat \beta_2\) indicates how body mass changes from Adelie to Gentoo.


\(\hat \beta_0\) represents the baseline level, in this case the body mass of Adelie.

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Fitting a Model in R

lm(Y ~ X, data = DATA)


X: Name Predictor Variable of Interest in data frame DATA, must be a factor variable
Y: Name Outcome Variable of Interest in data frame DATA
DATA: Name of the data frame

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
X not a Factor

lm(Y ~ factor(X), data = DATA)


X: Name Predictor Variable of Interest in data frame DATA, not a factor variable
Y: Name Outcome Variable of Interest in data frame DATA
DATA: Name of the data frame

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Example

lm(body_mass_g ~ species, penguins)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = body_mass_g ~ species, data = penguins)
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>      (Intercept)  speciesChinstrap     speciesGentoo  
#>          3706.16             26.92           1386.27


\[
\hat Y_i = 3706 + 26.92 D_{1i} + 1386.27 D_{2i}
\]

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Finding the Adelie MASS
\[
\hat Y_i = 3706 + 26.92 (0) + 1386.27 (0)
\]

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Finding the Chinstrap MASS
\[
\hat Y_i = 3706 + 26.92 (1) + 1386.27 (0)
\]

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Finding the Gentoo MASS
\[
\hat Y_i = 3706 + 26.92 (0) + 1386.27 (1)
\]

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Intepreting \(\hat \beta_1\)
On average, Chinstrap has a larger mass than Adelie by about 26.92 grams.

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Intepreting \(\hat \beta_2\)
On average, Gentoo has a larger mass than Adelie by about 1386.27 grams.

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Correlation
Correlation is a statistics that can be used to describe the strength of the relationship between 2 continuous variables.

\[
r = \frac{1}{n-1}\sum^n_{i=1}\frac{x_i - \bar x}{s_x}\frac{y_i - \bar y}{s_y}
\]

\(\bar x\), \(\bar y\): sample means
\(s_x\), \(s_y\): sample standard deviations



\[
-1 \leq r \leq 1
\]

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Correlations

From IMS 2e

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Coefficient of Determination
The coefficient of determination evaluates the strength between an outcome \(Y\) and the linear model, which includes \(X\).

\[
R^2 = r^2
\]


\[
0 \leq R^2 \leq 1
\]


The coefficient of determination measures the total variation explained by the linear model. The closer to 1, the better the linear model.

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Correlation in R

cor(DATA$Y, DATA$X)


X: Name Predictor Variable of Interest in data frame DATA
Y: Name Outcome Variable of Interest in data frame DATA
DATA: Name of the data frame

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Example

cor(penguins$body_mass_g, penguins$flipper_length_mm)

#> [1] 0.8729789

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Coefficient of Determination in R

xlm <- lm(Y ~ X, data = DATA)
r2(xlm)


X: Name Predictor Variable of Interest in data frame DATA
Y: Name Outcome Variable of Interest in data frame DATA
DATA: Name of the data frame

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Example

xlm <- lm(body_mass_g ~ species, penguins)
r2(xlm)

#> [1] 0.6744887

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Statistical Model
\[
\hat Y = \hat \beta_0 + \hat \beta_1 X
\]

\(X\): Input
\(\hat Y\): Output

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Prediction
Using the equation \(\hat Y\), we can give it a value of \(X\) and then, in return, a value of \(\hat Y\) that predicts the true value \(Y\).

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Prediction in R

xlm <- lm(Y ~ X,
            data = DATA)

predict_df <- data.frame(X = VAL)

predict(xlm,
        predict_df)


X: Name Predictor Variable of Interest in data frame DATA
Y: Name Outcome Variable of Interest in data frame DATA
DATA: Name of the data frame
VAL: Value for the Predictor Variable

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Example 1

ExampleCode


Predict the body mass for a gentoo penguin.



xlm <- lm(body_mass_g ~ species,
            data = penguins)

xlm

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = body_mass_g ~ species, data = penguins)
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>      (Intercept)  speciesChinstrap     speciesGentoo  
#>          3706.16             26.92           1386.27

predict_df <- data.frame(species = "Gentoo")

predict(xlm,
        predict_df)

#>        1 
#> 5092.437

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Example 2

ExampleCode


Predict the body mass for a penguin with a flipper length of 190.



xlm <- lm(body_mass_g ~ flipper_length_mm,
            data = penguins)


xlm

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = body_mass_g ~ flipper_length_mm, data = penguins)
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>       (Intercept)  flipper_length_mm  
#>          -5872.09              50.15

predict_df <- data.frame(flipper_length_mm = 190)

predict(xlm,
        predict_df)

#>        1 
#> 3657.028

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Interpolation
Interpolation is the process of estimating a value within the range of the observed input data \(X\).

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Extrapolation
Extrapolation is the process of estimating a value beyond the range of observed input data \(X\). It’s about venturing into the unknown, using what we know as a guide.

title: Simple Linear Regression
text:
Extrapolation


Code
ggplot(penguins, aes(flipper_length_mm, body_mass_g)) + 
  xlim(160, 250) +
  ylim(2600, 7000) +
  geom_point() +
  stat_smooth(method = "lm", se = F)

title: Logistic Regression
text:
Melanoma
Melanoma is a type of skin cancer that causes the cells that produce melanin to grow out of control. What makes Melanoma so dangerous is that it can metastasize to other parts of the body.

title: Logistic Regression
text:
Outcome of Interest
We are interested in learning how do different factors affect and individual’s chances of survival. Therefore, we are measuring patients and if they lived or died during a study period.

title: Logistic Regression
text:
Data
We will be using the Melanoma data set with the following variables: dead (died by Melanoma, 1=yes, 0= no), sex (1 = male, 0 = female), age (in years), thickness (tumour thickness in mm), ulcer (1 = presence, 0 absent).

title: Logistic Regression
text:
Plot


Code
Melanoma |> 
  ggplot(aes(thickness, dead)) +
  geom_point()

title: Logistic Regression
text:
Construct Model
\[
\left(\begin{array}{c}
Dead \\
Alive
\end{array}\right) = \beta_0 + \beta_1X
\]

title: Logistic Regression
text:
Let …
\[
Y = \left\{\begin{array}{cc}
1 & Dead \\
0 & Alive
\end{array}\right.
\]

title: Logistic Regression
text:
Construct a Model
\[
P\left(Y = 1\right) = \beta_0 + \beta_1X
\]

title: Logistic Regression
text:
Construct a Model
\[
P\left(Y = 1\right) = \frac{e^{\beta_0 + \beta_1X}}{1 + e^{\beta_0 + \beta_1X}}
\]

title: Logistic Regression
text:
Construct a Model
\[
\frac{P(Y = 1)}{P(Y = 0)} = e^{\beta_0 + \beta_1X}
\]
where \(\frac{P(Y = 1)}{P(Y = 0)}\) are considered the odds of observing \(Y = 1\).

title: Logistic Regression
text:
The Logistic Model
\[
\log\left\{\frac{P(Y = 1)}{P(Y = 0)}\right\} = \beta_0 + \beta_1X
\]

title: Logistic Regression
text:
Logistic Regression
Logistic Regression is used to model the association between a set of predictors and a binary outcome variable.

This is similar Linear Regression which models the association between a set of predictors and a numerical outcome variable.

title: Logistic Regression
text:
Logistic Regression
Logistic Regression uses the logistic model to formulate the relationship between the predictors and the outcome.

More specifically, for an outcome of Y:
\[
Y = \left\{\begin{array}{cc}
1 & \text{Category 1} \\
0 & \text{Category 2}
\end{array}\right.
\]
The Predictors variable will model the probability of observing category 1 (\(P(Y=1)\))

title: Logistic Regression
text:
Logistic Model
\[
\log\left\{\frac{P(Y = 1)}{P(Y = 0)}\right\} = \beta_0 + \beta_1X
\]

title: Logistic Regression
text:
Regression Coefficients \(\beta\)
The regression coefficients quantify how a specific predictor changes the odds of observing the first category of the outcome (\(Y = 1\))

title: Logistic Regression
text:
Estimating \(\beta\)
To obtain the numerical value for \(\beta\), denoted as \(\hat \beta\), we will be finding the values of \(\hat \beta\) that maximizes the likelihood function:
\[
L(\boldsymbol \beta) = \prod_{i=1}^n \left(\frac{e^{\beta_0 + \beta_1X}}{1 + e^{\beta_0 + \beta_1X}}\right)^{Y_i}\left(\frac{1}{1 + e^{\beta_0 + \beta_1X}}\right)^{1-Y_i}
\]
The likelihood function can be thought as the probability of observing the entire data set. Therefore, we want to choose the values the \(\beta_0\) and \(\beta_1\) that will result in the highest probability of observing the data.

title: Logistic Regression
text:
Estimated Parameters
The values you obtain (\(\hat \beta\)) tell you the relationship between the a predictor variable and the log odds of observing the first category of the outcome \(Y=1\).

Exponentiating the estimate (\(e^{\hat \beta}\)) will give you the relationship between a predictor variable and the odds of observing the first category of the outcome \(Y=1\).

title: Logistic Regression
text:
Interpreting \(\hat \beta\)
For a continuous predictor variable:
As X increases by 1 unit, the odds of observing the first category (\(Y = 1\)) increases by a factor of \(e^{\hat\beta}\).
For a categorical predictor variable (first dummy variable):
The odds of observing the first category (\(Y = 1\)) in the indicated category (\(D=1\)) is \(e^{\hat\beta}\) times higher/lower compared to the reference category (\(D=0\)).

title: Logistic Regression
text:
Logistic Regression in R


Code
glm(Y ~ X1 + X2 + ... + Xp,
    data = DATA,
    family = binomial())

title: Logistic Regression
text:
Example
Modelling dead by sex, age, thickness, and ulcer:


Code
glm(dead ~ sex + age + thickness + ulcer,
    data = Melanoma,
    family = binomial())


#> 
#> Call:  glm(formula = dead ~ sex + age + thickness + ulcer, family = binomial(), 
#>     data = Melanoma)
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#> (Intercept)          sex          age    thickness        ulcer  
#>    -2.39860      0.40767      0.00402      0.11253      1.31314  
#> 
#> Degrees of Freedom: 204 Total (i.e. Null);  200 Residual
#> Null Deviance:       242.4 
#> Residual Deviance: 210.3     AIC: 220.3


\[
\log(odds) = -2.40 + 0.41 M + 0.004 age + 0.11 thick + 1.31ulc
\]

title: Logistic Regression
text:
Interpretation
\[
\log(odds) = -2.40 + 0.41 M + 0.004 age + 0.11 thick + 1.31ulc
\]

The odds of experiencing death in males is 1.5 times larger than the odds for females, adjusting for age, tumor thickness and the presence of an ulcer.


As age increases by 1 year, the odds of experiencing death increases by a factor of 1.004, adjusting for sex, tumor thickness and presence of an ulcer.

title: Logistic Regression
text:
Working with probabilities
As you can see, working with odds may be unintuitive for the average person. It will be better to predict the probability and display those results to individuals.

title: Logistic Regression
text:
Predicting Probability
\[
\hat P\left(Y = 1\right) = \frac{e^{\hat\beta_0 + \hat\beta_1X_1 + \cdots  + \hat \beta_pX_p}}{1 + e^{\hat\beta_0 + \hat\beta_1X_1 + \cdots  + \hat \beta_pX_p}}
\]

title: Logistic Regression
text:
Prediction in R


Code
xglm <- glm(Y ~ X1 + X2 + ... + Xp,
            data = DATA,
            family = binomial())
predict_df <- data.frame(X1 = VAL,  X2 = VAL, ..., Xp = VAL)
predict(xglm,
        predict_df,
        type = "response")

title: Logistic Regression
text:
Example 1
Predict the probability of observing death for a patient who is male, 75 years old, an tumor thickness of 2.9, and with ulcer presence.


Code
xglm <- glm(dead ~ sex + age + thickness + ulcer,
    data = Melanoma,
    family = binomial())
predict_df <- data.frame(sex = 1, age = 75, thickness = 2.9, ulcer = 1)
predict(xglm, predict_df, type = "response")


#>         1 
#> 0.4875223

title: Logistic Regression
text:
Example 1
Predict the probability of observing death for a patient who is male, 75 years old, an tumor thickness of 2.9, and without ulcer presence.


Code
xglm <- glm(dead ~ sex + age + thickness + ulcer,
    data = Melanoma,
    family = binomial())
predict_df <- data.frame(sex = 1, age = 75, thickness = 2.9, ulcer = 0)
predict(xglm, predict_df, type = "response")


#>         1 
#> 0.2037438

title: Logistic Regression
text:
Example 1




Ulcer Present
Ulcer not Present




Probabiltiy
48.7%
20.3%



For a patient who is 75 years old, male, and a tumor thickness of 2.9, when an ulcer is present, the probability a patient dies increases to 48% compared to a patient who does not have an ulcer with a probability of 20%.

title: Logistic Regression
text:
Example 2
Predict the probability of observing death for a patient who is female, 75 years old, an tumor thickness of 2.9, and with ulcer presence.


Code
xglm <- glm(dead ~ sex + age + thickness + ulcer,
    data = Melanoma,
    family = binomial())
predict_df <- data.frame(sex = 0, age = 75, thickness = 2.9, ulcer = 1)
predict(xglm, predict_df, type = "response")


#>         1 
#> 0.3875575

title: Logistic Regression
text:
Example 2
Predict the probability of observing death for a patient who is female, 55 years old, an tumor thickness of 2.9, and with ulcer presence.


Code
xglm <- glm(dead ~ sex + age + thickness + ulcer,
    data = Melanoma,
    family = binomial())
predict_df <- data.frame(sex = 0, age = 55, thickness = 2.9, ulcer = 1)
predict(xglm, predict_df, type = "response")


#>         1 
#> 0.3686531

title: Logistic Regression
text:
Example 2




55
75




Probabiltiy
36.8%
38.7%



For a patient who is female, a tumor thickness of 2.9, and has an ulcer, the probability a 75 year old patient dies increases to 38.7% compared to a 55 year old patient with a probability of 36.8%.
